Class Player

  • java.lang.Object
    • Player
  • Direct Known Subclasses:
    AggressivePlayer, BalancedPlayer, DefensivePlayer

    public abstract class Player
extends java.lang.Object
    The Player class represents the players in the game. The game iterates through the players and calls the turn() function of each.
    Author:
    Graham Netherton

        Zero argument constructor for the Player class.

        public Player(java.lang.String n)
        Constructor for the Player class that sets the name.
        Parameters:
        n - The name to give the player.

    • Method Detail

      • getName

        public java.lang.String getName()
        Returns the AI's personal name. Used for identifying what code each AI is running.
        Returns:
        The AI's personal name as a string.

      • setName

        public void setName(java.lang.String n)

      • setGraph

        public void setGraph(Graph g)
        Sets the player's associated graph.
        Parameters:
        g - The graph to associate the player with.

      • showError

        public void showError(java.lang.String error)
        Outputs an error message to the console.
        Parameters:
        error - A string containing the error message, or null for no message.

      • hasLost

        public boolean hasLost()
        Determines if this player has lost.
        Returns:
        True if the player has lost, false if they haven't.

      • attack

        public boolean attack(Node from,
             Node to,
             int num)
        Attacks an unowned node using units from an owned one. Returns a boolean indicating if an error occurred. Call this any number of times from turn().
        Parameters:
        from - The node the attack is originating from.
        to - The node the attack is being made towards.
        num - The number of units being used to attack.
        Returns:
        True if there was an error, false if there wasn't.

      • fortify

        public boolean fortify(Node from,
              Node to,
              int num)
        Fortifies one node using units from another. Returns a boolean indicating if there was an error. Call this function once at the end of turn().
        Parameters:
        from - Node to transfer from.
        to - Node to transfer to.
        num - Number of units to transfer.
        Returns:
        True if there was an error, false if there wasn't.

      • defend

        abstract int defend(Node from,
         Node to,
         int num)
        To be implemented by each individual AI. This function should contain the AI's logic for deciding how many units to use when defending against an attack.
        Parameters:
        from - The node the attack is originating from.
        to - The node the attack is being made towards.
        num - The number of units being used to attack.
        Returns:
        The number of units being used to defend.

      • occupy

        abstract int occupy(Node from,
         Node to)
        To be implemented by each individual AI. This function should contain the AI's logic for deciding how many units to move into a new node that is gained from a successful attack.
        Parameters:
        from - The node the units are moving from.
        to - The node the units are moving to.
        Returns:
        The number of units to move.

      • place

        abstract Node place()
        To be implemented by each individual AI. This function should contain the AI's logic for deciding where to place new units. It should be able to function in all of these conditions: no units in any of the nodes, units in some of the nodes, and units in all of the nodes.
        Returns:
        The node where the unit should be placed.

      • turn

        abstract void turn()
        To be implemented by each individual AI. This function should contain the AI's actual decision-making process. The player should never call this function by itself; it will always be called externally.
